channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Warplane Hits American Drone Over Black Sea, U.S. Says: Live Updates
item.description: A U.S. military official said that an American Reaper drone was brought down in international waters after one of two intercepting Russian jets hit its propeller. Russia denied that the jet made contact.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Flood of Russians Alters Life for Countries That Took Them In
item.description: Russians, fleeing their country and its war, have quickly reshaped the societies of nations like Georgia and Armenia.
item.dc:creator: Sergey Ponomarev and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Cyclone Freddy Brings Mudslides and Floods, Leaving Nearly 200 Dead in Malawi
item.description: The record-breaking storm barreled across southeastern Africa into landlocked Malawi, where rescue workers searched for survivors as rain kept falling.
item.dc:creator: Golden Matonga and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Heavy rains caused by Cyclone Freddy cratered a road in Malawi that had connected the cities of Blantyre and Lilongwe.

item.title: Who Was Leonardo’s Mother? A Novelist Has Evidence She Was Enslaved.
item.description: An author has a theory that the artist’s mother, Caterina, was kidnapped as a girl in the Caucasus area of Central Asia.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A news conference about the book “Caterina’s Smile” in Florence, Italy, on Tuesday. It is a historical novel based on evidence about the origins of Leonardo da Vinci’s mother.

item.title: An Oil Rush Threatens Natural Splendors Across East Africa
item.description: A multibillion-dollar oil drilling and pipeline project is displacing thousands of people in Uganda and Tanzania, and ravaging pristine habitats. Environmentalists are fighting to stop it, but the governments are all in.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Arlette Bashizi
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times
item.media:description: African elephants walk near trees in Murchison Falls National Park, northwestern Uganda, in January.

item.title: Macron Faces Pivotal Week in His Attempt to Change France at Its Core
item.description: Huge crowds are again expected to protest President Emmanuel Macron’s plan to raise the retirement age before a decisive vote that could redefine his nation and his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, shown in April in Paris, has been met with huge street protests over his plan to raise the legal age of retirement to 64 from 62.

item.title: Prigozhin, Head of Wagner, Plots Political Advance in Russia
item.description: Yevgeny Prigozhin says his Wagner force will shrink when the battle for the Ukrainian city of Bakhmut is done. Now he’s maneuvering on the home front, for the favor of President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Yevgeny Prigozhin, right, the founder of the Wagner private military company, in September at a memorial service for a Wagner fighter in Volgograd, Russia.

item.title: 10 Years On, Pope Francis Faces Challenges From the Right and the Left
item.description: In an ideologically divided Roman Catholic Church, the right has accused him of going too far and the left of not going far enough.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Many of the faithful are wondering whether Pope Francis will make concrete and transformative change or decide once and for all that such shifts will not happen.

item.title: For Elite Russians, Dubai Becomes a Wartime Harbor
item.description: In the exclusive neighborhoods and palatial shopping malls of the United Arab Emirates’ biggest city, wealthy Russians can build a new life without having to cut ties to their home country.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Andrea DiCenzo
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times

item.title: International Court to Open War Crimes Cases Against Russia, Officials Say
item.description: The cases before the International Criminal Court would accuse Russia of abducting Ukrainian children and of deliberately targeting civilian infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin and the commissioner for children’s rights, Maria Lvova-Belova, last month.

item.title: To Rein in China’s Banks, Xi Uses Familiar Playbook
item.description: Xi Jinping is revamping China’s regulatory framework so the ruling Communist Party can assert more direct control over financial policy.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
item.media:description: Local coverage, on a television in Beijing, of Xi Jinping after he was elected to a third term as China’s president on Friday.

item.title: France’s Pension Plan Strikes, Explained
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is forging ahead with plans to raise the legal age of retirement to 64, from 62, despite strikes, wide public opposition and a two-month showdown with labor unions.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Protesters in Nantes, France, during a nationwide strike in late January to voice anger over proposed changes to the pension system.

item.title: China’s New Premier Needs to Revive Growth. How Far Will Loyalty Get Him?
item.description: Li Qiang’s business-friendly reputation could bolster confidence in China’s economy. But he is stepping into a role with diminished power under Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Chang Che
item.media:description: China’s new premier, Li Qiang, taking an oath after being endorsed in a ritual vote by the country’s rubber-stamp legislature on Saturday.

item.title: A Mossad Agent’s Treasure Trove of Photos
item.description: Sylvia Rafael worked undercover as a news agency photographer. Her pictures for the Israeli spy agency sat in its archives for decades before being released for a show.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Sylvia Rafael, a photographer and Mossad agent, in Yemen in 1967.

item.title: The Black Sea Is a Crucial Theater in the War Between Russia and Ukraine
item.description: Long dominated by Russia’s navy, the Black Sea has been the scene of Ukrainian defiance. It’s also been a rare point of agreement between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Black Sea seen from Cape Fiolent, outside the Crimean port city of Sevastopol, in 2018.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Downed U.S. Drone
item.description: Also, U.S. markets seem to stabilize and Xi Jinping tightens his control over China’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An MQ-9 Reaper drone at a Naval Air Station at Sigonella, Sicily, in 2022. The U.S. European Command said the same model of drone was downed after being intercepted by Russian warplanes over the Black Sea.

item.title: Polish Court Convicts Rights Activist of Aiding an Abortion by Providing Pills
item.description: It was the first conviction of its type in the country and in Europe, offering a glimpse of the implications of a near-total ban on abortion.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Supporters of the rights activist Justyna Wydrzynska awaiting her arrival at court in Warsaw on Tuesday.

item.title: The U.S. Program That Brought H.I.V. Treatment to 20 Million People
item.description: Over two decades, Pepfar may have saved an estimated 25 million lives, helping to slow the AIDS pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: In Uganda, one of the first countries supported by Pepfar, the program has prevented nearly half a million H.I.V. infections since 2004 and saved more than 600,000 lives.

item.title: EPA to Restrict Toxic PFAS Chemicals in Drinking Water
item.description: The government will strictly limit in drinking water two chemicals that are ubiquitous in modern society but are linked to a range of health effects.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jake May/The Flint Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: PFAS, an abbreviation for perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances, are a class of compounds dubbed “forever chemicals” because they do not break down and persist in the environment, seeping into soil and water.

item.title: This Dress Survived for More Than Three Centuries at the Bottom of the Sea
item.description: Divers found an almost perfectly preserved dress in the remains of a ship that sank off the Netherlands in the 1600s. Researchers are trying to figure out who owned the garment.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Jiang Yanyong, Who Helped Expose China’s SARS Crisis, Dies at 91
item.description: A retired military surgeon, he blew the whistle in 2003 on Beijing’s cover-up of the epidemic. He was later punished for denouncing the Tiananmen Square crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Simon Song/South China Morning Post via Getty Images
item.media:description: Dr. Jiang Yanyong in 2013, 10 years after the SARS outbreak in China. “I was telling the truth,” he said. “I believed the government would treat me fairly.”

item.title: Gary Glitter Is Back in Prison After Violating Probation Terms
item.description: The singer was released from prison last month after serving half of a 16-year sentence for sexually abusing three young girls decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Following his release from prison in February, Gary Glitter had been fitted with a GPS tag and faced other restrictions.

item.title: The Bank Failures, Explained
item.description: Officials are worried that a few banks’ collapse is only the beginning.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Silicon Valley Bank in Santa Clara, Calif.

item.title: Russian Attacks Along a Wide Arc of Ukraine Yield Little but Casualties
item.description: Moscow’s forces have stepped up artillery and infantry assaults across eastern Ukraine, trying to improve their position before either side attempts a major breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in a trench outside Toretsk in Donetsk Province on Saturday. Russian forces are attacking along a 160-mile arc in eastern Ukraine in an intensifying struggle for tactical advantage.

item.title: Biden Extends Stay for Thousands of Ukrainians
item.description: One-year extensions for those who fled in the first months after Russia’s invasion will be granted on a case-by-case basis, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants from Ukraine waited at the U.S.-Mexico border in 2022, before being allowed to enter the United States.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A U.S. Banking Crisis
item.description: Also, Russia is set to face war crimes charges and China’s new premier seeks to reassure investors.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Clients stood in line outside Silicon Valley Bank waiting to enter in Santa Clara, Cali., on Monday.

item.title: Cyclone Freddy Persists, Leaving Scores More Dead in Africa
item.description: A storm that has broken records for its longevity — now 35 days — swept inland from the southeastern coast of Africa and is causing massive flooding and displacement.
item.dc:creator: Golden Matonga and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Searching for victims of Cyclone Freddy in Blantyre, Malawi, on Monday.

item.title: ‘Navalny’ Wins Oscar for Best Documentary and His Wife Issues Message of Defiance
item.description: The film followed Aleksei Navalny, a prominent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, as he investigated his own near-fatal poisoning in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Yulia Navalnaya, wife of jailed dissident Alexei Navalny, and her daughter Dasha, accepted the award for best documentary feature film with the creators of “Navalny,” at the Oscars on Sunday.

item.title: The fallout from Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse spreads to an Indian tech company.
item.description: Nazara Technologies, a mobile gaming company, said two of its subsidiaries had together more than $7.7 million in balances at the failed bank.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Nazara Technologies headquarters in Mumbai in 2021. The company said that operations at its subsidiaries were not affected by the American bank’s collapse.

item.title: A New Bank Panic?
item.description: It’s a day of uncertainty for the U.S. economy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Silicon Valley Bank in Santa Clara, Calif.

item.title: Gary Lineker to Return to BBC Soccer Show ‘Match of the Day’
item.description: The move calmed a crisis at the publicly funded broadcaster after Gary Lineker, a former soccer star, was removed from a flagship show because of a tweet about immigration policy.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Gary Lineker is a former captain of the England men’s soccer team and host of the popular “Match of the Day” highlight show on the BBC.

item.title: Biden to Announce Nuclear-Powered Submarine Deal with Australia and Britain
item.description: The arrangement is part of a broader effort to counter China’s military development and assertive territorial claims across Asia.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Edward Wong
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden met with leaders of Britain and Australia on Monday.

item.title: Grain deal, Bakhmut and more: What to watch for this week.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A grain storage facility in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, in February.

item.title: Zelensky names a soldier whose death was captured on video a Hero of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Randy Pennell
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still frame of a video of a Ukrainian soldier whose execution was filmed.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The collapse of three U.S. banks in a week.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Signature Bank, which was shut down on Sunday by New York regulators.

item.title: North Korea Launches Cruise Missiles From Submarine
item.description: The missile test, the first of its kind carried out by the North, took place as South Korea and the United States were about to begin joint military exercises.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A news broadcast about North Korea at a train station in Seoul on Friday.

item.title: Biden Administration Approves Willow Oil Project in Alaska, Officials Say
item.description: The administration also announced new limits on Arctic drilling in an apparent effort to temper criticism over the $8 billion Willow oil project, which has faced sharp opposition.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A drilling camp at the proposed site of the Willow oil project on Alaska’s North Slope.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: China’s Saudi-Iran Deal
item.description: Also, Xi Jinping loyalists stack China’s leadership and Australia revives an Aboriginal alcohol ban.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/West Asia News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A newspapers with a cover photo of Wang Yi, center, China’s top foreign policy official, with Ali Shamkhani, right, the secretary of Iran’s security council, and Musaad bin Mohammed Al Aiban, Saudi Arabia’s minister of state, seen in Tehran, Iran, on Sunday.

item.title: Spiraling Dispute With Star Host Puts BBC’s Reputation on the Line
item.description: The British public broadcaster’s suspension of one of its highest-profile sports anchors has grown into a wider controversy that poses risks to its reputation for neutrality and independence.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Gary Lineker on Sunday near his home in London. He is the BBC’s highest-paid on-air personality, and a former England soccer captain.

item.title: War in Ukraine Puts Centuries of Swiss Neutrality to the Test
item.description: The Alpine state makes arms that Western allies want to send to Kyiv. Swiss law bans this, driving a national debate about whether its concept of neutrality should change.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A Leopard 2 tank during a Swiss military exercise in November. Some of the tanks are made in Switzerland, as is ammunition for some other Western weapons.

item.title: Authorities Reinstate Alcohol Ban for Aboriginal Australians
item.description: The reaction to a rise in crime has renewed hard questions about race and control, and about the open wounds of discrimination.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Tamati Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Alice Springs, Australia, where for a decade and a half it was illegal for Indigenous Australians to possess alcohol.

item.title: The First Book of Spring
item.description: A book can be an accomplice in a coup against winter.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson

item.title: Ukraine Steps Up Calls for Evacuation of Kupiansk Under Relentless Russian Shelling
item.description: Attacks on the northeast town in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine continued on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:description: The damaged House of Culture in Kupiansk, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: How the Saudi-Iran Pact Could Transform the Middle East
item.description: Both countries as well as the broader region have much to gain from the reset in relations — if the agreement truly holds.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A photograph released by Chinese state media showing Wang Yi, center, China’s top foreign policy official, with Ali Shamkhani, right, the secretary of Iran’s security council, and Musaad bin Mohammed Al Aiban, Saudi Arabia’s minister of state, in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: Restoring Glory of Angola’s Carnival, With a Puny Budget but Much Passion
item.description: A singer and son of a music legend is trying to once again make the Carnival celebration a highlight of the year — and to make it a year-round force for positive change in Angola.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Gulshan Khan
item.media:description: Performing for Carnival in Luanda, Angola, last month. Once a cultural highlight that seized the streets of this port city, Carnival seems to barely register a blip these days.

item.title: With Fingerprints, DNA and Photos, Turkey Seeks Families of the Missing
item.description: More than a thousand earthquake victims are still unaccounted for. Some families waited for days by ruined buildings, hoping to see bodies that never surfaced.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paying respects to four family members who were buried at a cemetery this month in Antakya, Turkey. Thousands in Turkey are still missing.

item.title: An Activist’s Flight Reveals Widening Repression in Algeria
item.description: Four years after a popular uprising fueled hopes for change and real democracy, the country’s government is using vaguely defined statutes to round up hundreds.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amira Bouraoui’s case is part of what academics and human rights groups have described as an intensifying crackdown by the Algerian government on civil society.

item.title: How Mia Couto’s Words Help Weave the Story of Mozambique
item.description: Couto’s language is enriched by his country’s idioms, voices — and possibilities. “We are still in the process of creating one nation,” he said, made of “different languages, different beliefs.”
item.dc:creator: Jacob Judah
item.media:credit: Nii Obodai for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We are building myths,” said Mia Couto of the role of writers in Mozambique. “We are still in the process of creating one nation; one nation that can bring together these different languages, different beliefs. We are substitutes for the prophets.”

item.title: Corruption Watchdog Moves to Clear Cyril Ramaphosa
item.description: After $580,000 was stolen from a sofa of President Cyril Ramaphosa, his head of security skirted regulations, but the president did not, according to a preliminary report by a corruption watchdog.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa speaking during the opening of the African National Congress 55th national conference in Johannesburg in December.

item.title: China’s Role in Iran-Saudi Deal Shows Xi’s Challenge to U.S.-led Order
item.description: Brokering a rapprochement between the Middle Eastern rivals underscores the Chinese leader’s ambition of offering an alternative to a U.S.-led world order.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Wang Yi, center, China’s top foreign policy official, with Ali Shamkhani, right, the secretary of Iran’s security council, and Musaad al-Aiban, Saudi Arabia’s minister of state, in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: It’s Oscar Time
item.description: Get your popcorn. Manage your expectations. The 95th Academy Awards are tomorrow.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A National Medical License May Ease Canada’s Doctor Shortages
item.description: The Canadian Medical Association is pushing for a single license to eliminate the barriers between provinces and territories.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: Applying for a medical license in another province is costly and time-consuming.

item.title: Front Line Shifts in Russia and Ukraine’s Bakhmut Battle, Analysts Say
item.description: Britain’s defense intelligence agency said that Russian forces had taken control of most of Bakhmut’s east, but advances farther west might be challenging.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers targeting Russian forces to support their infantry near Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Inside One of the World’s Biggest Green Hydrogen Projects
item.description: Hundreds of billions of dollars are being invested in a high-tech gamble to make hydrogen clean, cheap and widely available. In Australia’s Outback, that starts with 10 million new solar panels.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Giacomo d’Orlando
item.media:credit: Giacomo d'Orlando for The New York Times

item.title: In Fields Sown With Bombs, Ukraine’s Farmers Risk Deadly Harvest
item.description: Some who till the breadbaskets of Ukraine have already lost three seasons of planting to war. With mines and cluster bombs widely scattered, normal harvests seem far in the future.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Stanislav Kozliuk and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Hordienko, right, and Serhii Mikhailechko checked for mines near the site where a family were killed when they drove over a Russian anti-tank mine in the Beryslav region of Ukraine, in February.

item.title: Trial in ‘Argentina, 1985’ Began Quest for Justice That Continues Today
item.description: “Argentina, 1985” has resurrected the country’s military rule, which ended 40 years ago. The quest persists to hold those accused of crimes against humanity accountable.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pictures of missing people at the Naval Mechanics School, also known as the ESMA, a former clandestine center for detention, torture and killings, in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Iran-Saudi Pact Is Brokered by China, Leaving U.S. on Sidelines
item.description: The agreement negotiated in Beijing to restore relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran signaled at least a temporary reordering of the usual alliances and rivalries, with Washington left on the sidelines.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: A photograph released by Chinese state media showing officials Wang Yi, center, China’s top foreign policy official, with Ali Shamkhani, right, the secretary of Iran’s security council, and Musaad bin Mohammed Al Aiban, Saudi Arabia’s minister of state, in Beijing, on Friday.

item.title: In World Cup Run-Up, Qatar Pressed U.N. Agency Not to Investigate Abuses
item.description: Lobbying at the International Labor Organization dovetailed with an influence campaign that set off a corruption scandal at the European Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz and Sarah Hurtes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A worker during the World Cup in November in Doha, Qatar. The country, which has spent years tamping down criticism of its human rights record, lobbied influential labor groups in the build-up to the tournament.

item.title: The Tech Worker With a 4-Hour Commute From the West Bank to Tel Aviv
item.description: Moha Alshawamreh is among the few Palestinians who work in Israel’s tech industry. His commute shows both the inequities of life in the West Bank and an exception to them.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moha Alshawamreh in his village, Deir al-Asal al-Fauqa. It lies just east of a gray wall, hundreds of miles long, that Israel built to curb Palestinian attacks from the West Bank.

item.title: Biden Administration Expected to Move Ahead on a Major Oil Project in Alaska
item.description: The decision would allow an enormous $8 billion drilling project in the largest expanse of pristine wilderness in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists gathered outside the White House this month to call on President Biden to halt the Willow Project in Alaska.

item.title: BBC in Turmoil as Revolt Over Gary Lineker’s ‘Match of the Day’ Suspension Spreads
item.description: One of England’s best-known sports personalities, he was taken off the air after criticizing a British government immigration proposal on social media. His ouster set off a staff boycott.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das, Michael Levenson and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Mr. Lineker has frequently engaged in debates on social media, which has sometimes led to criticism that he is violating the BBC’s guidelines on impartiality.

item.title: Criminals in Mexico Violated Their Unwritten Rule: Leave Americans Alone
item.description: While Mexicans are often caught in cartel violence, and the outside world barely notices, the criminal groups know that targeting Americans is bad for business.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers on patrol outside the Forensic Medical Service morgue building in Matamoros, Mexico, on Wednesday.

item.title: Saudi Deal With Iran Surprises Israel and Jolts Netanyahu
item.description: Israel had long hoped to isolate Iran and seal ties with Saudi Arabia. A thaw between Riyadh and Tehran has complicated that goal — and was perceived as politically damaging to the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during a cabinet meeting at the prime minister’s office in Jerusalem, last month.
